metadata.title: PATE-GAN: GENERATING SYNTHETIC DATA WITH DIFFERENTIAL PRIVACY GUARANTEES
metadata.author: James Jordon, Engineering Science Department University of Oxford, UK james.jordon@wolfson.ox.ac.uk
metadata.abstract: Machine learning has the potential to assist many communities in using the large datasets that are becoming more and more available. Unfortunately, much of that potential is not being realized because it would require sharing data in a way that compromises privacy. In this paper, we investigate a method for ensuring (differential) privacy of the generator of the Generative Adversarial Nets (GAN) framework. The resulting model can be used for generating synthetic data on which algorithms can be trained and validated, and on which competitions can be conducted, without compromising the privacy of the original dataset. Our method modifies the Private Aggregation of Teacher Ensembles (PATE) framework and applies it to GANs. Our modified framework (which we call PATE-GAN) allows us to tightly bound the influence of any individual sample on the model, resulting in tight differential privacy guarantees and thus an improved performance over models with the same guarantees. We also look at measuring the quality of synthetic data from a new angle; we assert that for the synthetic data to be useful for machine learning researchers, the relative performance of two algorithms (trained and tested) on the synthetic dataset should be the same as their relative performance (when trained and tested) on the original dataset. Our experiments, on various datasets, demonstrate that PATE-GAN consistently outperforms the stateof-the-art method with respect to this and other notions of synthetic data quality.

highlights: More and more large datasets are becoming available in a wide variety of communities

Using two Kaggle datasets, two different real-world medical datasets and two UCI datasets, we evaluate the utility of the samples generated by PRIVATE AGGREGATION OF TEACHER ENSEMBLES-Generative Adversarial Networks in various settings with various levels of differential privacy

We report the performance of the original Generative Adversarial Networks framework (”Generative Adversarial Networks”), which serves to indicate an upper bound on performance and allows us to see how much performance is lost due to the two differential privacy mechanisms (PATE-Generative Adversarial Networks and DPGAN)
We evaluate PRIVATE AGGREGATION OF TEACHER ENSEMBLES-Generative Adversarial Networks and DPGAN in Setting B to understand whether or not the models are capturing the feature-label relationships well
We see that PRIVATE AGGREGATION OF TEACHER ENSEMBLES-Generative Adversarial Networks is capable of generating synthetic samples that better preserve the feature-label relationship than DPGAN
Through several experiments we demonstrated the ability of our method to produce high quality synthetic data while being able to give strict differential privacy guarantees
key_statements: More and more large datasets are becoming available in a wide variety of communities

Using two Kaggle datasets, two different real-world medical datasets and two UCI datasets, we evaluate the utility of the samples generated by PRIVATE AGGREGATION OF TEACHER ENSEMBLES-Generative Adversarial Networks in various settings with various levels of differential privacy

For both of these methods, PRIVATE AGGREGATION OF TEACHER ENSEMBLES-Generative Adversarial Networks consistently produces synthetic datasets that are ”more like” the original real dataset than the synthetic datasets produced by the state-of-the-art benchmark (DPGAN [32])

The PRIVATE AGGREGATION OF TEACHER ENSEMBLES mechanism provides a differentially private method for classification, a core component of the Generative Adversarial Networks framework; the discriminator is a classifier trained to identify whether samples are real/fake
The proposed method builds on Generative Adversarial Networks and PRIVATE AGGREGATION OF TEACHER ENSEMBLES frameworks

We report the performance of the original Generative Adversarial Networks framework (”Generative Adversarial Networks”), which serves to indicate an upper bound on performance and allows us to see how much performance is lost due to the two differential privacy mechanisms (PATE-Generative Adversarial Networks and DPGAN)
We evaluate PRIVATE AGGREGATION OF TEACHER ENSEMBLES-Generative Adversarial Networks and DPGAN in Setting B to understand whether or not the models are capturing the feature-label relationships well

If a synthetic dataset is such that a model trained on it performs well when performance is measured on real data, the relationship between feature and label in the synthetic data is similar to that in the real data
In Table 2, we give the performance on each dataset averaged across the 12 methods for each of the 6 datasets

In this paper we introduced a novel methodology for generating differentially private synthetic data
Through several experiments we demonstrated the ability of our method to produce high quality synthetic data while being able to give strict differential privacy guarantees
summary: More and more large datasets are becoming available in a wide variety of communities.

Using two Kaggle datasets, two different real-world medical datasets and two UCI datasets, we evaluate the utility of the samples generated by PATE-GAN in various settings with various levels of differential privacy.
The first method, first proposed in [15], compares the predictive performance of models trained on the synthetic datasets and tested on the real dataset.

The contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows: (1) we modify the PATE framework and apply it to GANs to generate synthetic data, (2) we demonstrate in the experiments section that using PATE to enforce differential privacy results in higher quality synthetic data than DPGAN using various real-world datasets, (3) we propose a novel new metric for evaluating the generated synthetic data.
The key to the GAN framework is that the discriminator is a differentiable module trained to classify samples as either real or generated.
The PATE framework provides a differentially private mechanism for classification by training multiple teacher models on disjoint partitions of the data.

The PATE mechanism provides a differentially private method for classification, a core component of the GAN framework; the discriminator is a classifier trained to identify whether samples are real/fake.

The student, S, is a classifier that is trained by taking some public, unlabelled data, P = {xi}Ki=1, passing each sample, xi, through the PATE mechanism, to receive a differentially private label, yi, and forming a newteacher-labelled dataset P = {}Ki=1 on which the student is trained.
We replace the GAN discriminator with a PATE mechanism so that our discriminator is differentially private, but require the student version to allow back-propagation to the generator.

That the student training paradigm described in [25] would involve training the student using data similar to that used to train the generator - i.e. by taking an equal number of samples from each and labelling those using the standard PATEλ mechanism.
We use d real and d generated samples to train each teacher where d is the dimension of the input space.
We see that PATE-GAN is capable of generating synthetic samples that better preserve the feature-label relationship than DPGAN.

We believe this is because the PATE mechanism allows us to more tightly bound the influence of a single sample on the discriminator, and we can provide tighter differential privacy guarantees - when the differential privacy guarantee is fixed, this results in higher quality synthetic data.
headline: We investigate a method for ensuring privacy of the generator of the Generative Adversarial Nets framework
